contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks through Joel to the people of Israel using poetry. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
If your language has only one word for "weep" and "wail," you can combine the lines: "you people who love wine should cry out in sorrow" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: you drunkards, and weep! Wail, all you drinkers of wine

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines share similar meanings. The reference to the locusts' teeth being as sharp as lions' teeth emphasize how fierce they are as they eat all of the crops of the land. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: His teeth are the teeth of a lion, and he has the teeth of a lioness.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Joel continues poetry that began in the previous chapter. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
These two phrases share similar meanings. Both of them instruct the people to turn their farming tools into weapons. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Beat your plowshares into swords and your pruning knives into spears

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both phrases mean Yahweh will shout with a loud, clear and powerful voice from Jerusalem. If your language only has one word for speaking very loudly, this can be used as one phrase. Alternate translation: "Yahweh will shout from Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh will roar from Zion, and raise his voice from Jerusalem
